Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES Type 1: Hierarchical Energy Management for Sustainable Residential and Mobility Ecosystems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the proposed research is to study the integrated management of residential and personal transportation energy consumption to improve overall performance, efficiency, and reliability. The first goal of the proposal is to develop a highly resolved residential energy eco-system computational model that captures all energy consumption of an individual household, including energy for personal transportation. This can be either in the form of fossil fuels (gasoline, diesel, or natural gas) or electricity, in the case of plug-in electric vehicles. The second goal is to develop a hierarchical dynamic energy management framework for multiple interconnected energy eco-systems considering multiple energy carriers and the incorporation of stochastic human energy use behavior. The hierarchical energy management system optimally manages vehicle-building interactions for a group of residential buildings and associated vehicles. The management approach is non-disruptive, in the sense that consumers are not required to change their behavior. Deliverables include: a highly-resolved residential and transportation energy use computational model, validated using data from local utilities and from electric vehicle databases; a hierarchical energy management policy; the demonstration of the energy management policy in simulation; and an outreach component through the Ohio Energy Project.

The outcome of this work, if successful, will have a broad impact on energy efficiency, demand response, and on integration of multiple energy carriers and coordination among them -- all necessary conditions for the development of a sustainable energy system. Moreover, introduction of energy diversity in the residential-transportation sectors may significantly contribute to national energy independence. The results of this project have value beyond the immediate application considered here, since many of the advances required to realize the proposed model and optimization framework are directly transferable to other domains. In particular, the proposed modeling approach that quantifies stochastic consumer energy use behaviors provides a novel perspective to study complex interactions between human and technological systems, while the proposed hierarchical energy management framework that achieves the optimal tradeoff between population and individual objectives represents an effective strategy to control and manage sustainable infrastructure systems involving multiple participants. Dissemination of the results of the project to (utility and automotive) industry partners will enable greater societal impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies modeling, optimization, and control of residential energy eco-systems. The main objective is to develop fundamental tools to evaluate and improve energy efficiency and reliability in the residential area. The novelty of the project involves (i) joint management of residential and personal transportation energy consumptions, (ii) consideration of multiple energy carriers, and (iii) coordination of multiple residential eco-systems for maximized societal benefits. The outcome of the project involves a general residential eco-system modeling framework, optimal energy scheduling and management algorithms for individual eco-systems, and cooperative energy management methods for multiple residential eco-systems for maximized societal benefits.  

The first main outcome is the development of a general residential eco-system model for estimating the energy consumption, CO2 emissions and the operational cost of a single home. The model was developed based on a bottom-up approach that is independent of energy carriers. This enables the study of energy management with multiple energy carriers. In addition, the model incorporates stochastic end-use activities through a Markov chain model. The states of the Markov chain represent energy-consumption related human activities, and the transition probabilities between different activities are calibrated using real data. The model allows us to accurately predict the future energy demand, which is crucial for developing energy management strategies at both the individual eco-system layer and the coordinator layer. Moreover, the bottom-up nature of the model allows us to evaluate our energy management performance under a variety of “what-if” scenarios that cannot be directly obtained from the real data, such as different home sizes, different energy carriers, different numbers and types of vehicles, different smart appliances, among others. Together with the single household model, an optimal energy management problem for a single household has been formulated and an efficient algorithm has been developed to solve the problem. The algorithm has been shown to be flexible enough to optimize the appliance scheduling problems of different homes, while keeping the computation time numerically tractable for real applications.

Another main outcome of the project is the development of a hierarchical coordination strategy to optimize energy consumptions of multiple energy resources. Two representative cases have been studied. The first one involves the coordination of a large number of residential air conditioning (AC) systems in a residential area subject to a peak power consumption constraints. The main challenge of this problem lies in the heterogeneity of AC dynamics and user preferences and in how to align individual objectives with the coordinator objective. Leveraging concepts and results in economics, we developed a market-based approach to solve the coordination problem. The developed market mechanism consists of a novel bidding strategy and a market clearing strategy that incorporate the internal dynamics of TCLs in the design of the market mechanism. It is shown that the proposed mechanism can achieve the optimal social welfare for the entire population of TCLs. The second representative case involves operation planning for a community microgrid with not only controllable loads but also storage and renewable generations. The main challenge here lies in the intrinsic uncertainties associated with renewables and user activities. We proposed a chance constrained optimization formulation to formally study microgrid operation under uncertainties. We show that the resulting chance constrained optimization problem can be transformed into a convex optimization problem that can be efficiently solved with much improved system performance.

The results of this project have been disseminated through conference presentations and journal publications. The project also resulted in useful analytical and numerical tools to evaluate and improve energy efficiency and reliability in the future smart distribution systems with controllable loads, electric vehicles, storage devices, and renewable generations. The project has also impacted various education activities at the Ohio State University. Some of the results have been used as examples in the investigator’s class ECE7850 Hybrid Systems: Theory and Applications. The investigator has also supervised several undergraduate researchers in their labs working on sustainability issues. Several PhD students and a postdoctoral researcher (Dr. Stephanie Stockar) have received training through the project. In particular, the project has positively affected Dr. Stockar’s confidence as a student mentor and minority representative. She has recently become an assistant professor in Mechanical Engineering of Penn State University.
